bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 8, 1897

div1.p: Lazear writes that he is attempting to gain access to a medical library, even though he is on vacation in Massachusetts.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 8, 1897
div1.p:
I had
expected to get
a letter from you
before this. There
was one awaiting
us when we arrived
but there has been
none since.

I wonder if you
have the address
right. It is simply
Beverly, Mass.
This is a quaint old
town. It is right
on the sea but is
sheltered by several
small islands so
that there is no
surf. It is very
cool but rather
damp. There are
many interesting
places near. -- Salem
Gloucester, Marblehead.
The roads are good
for bicycle riding
Mabel has the use of her
sisters wheel and I rented
one a few days ago. We each
of us could ride from the
first. We took a six mile
ride the second time we
tried. There is some pleasure
in it, but I think it much
overestimated. It does not
compare with horseback
riding. The boating here
is excellent. Besides the
sea there is a pretty river.

I went in to Boston yesterday
for the first time. I have
a letter from Dr. Thayer to a
physician in Boston who can
get me the privileges of
the medical library. I brought
my microscope with
me and some stuff
that I want to
work at.

I forgot to say that
I did not find
the physician at home
so I shall have
to try again. I looked
over the new Public
Library which is
very beautiful indeed.
Are the Aspinwalls
in Hatley this summer.
I find that Mr. Aspinwalls
office is in the
same building with
Mr. Kilham's. I shall
call on him some
day.

We have a room
in the same house
with the Kilham's but
we shall probably
soon move to the
boarding house, as
the land-lady is not
very agreable.

The Kilham baby is
too young too be interesting.

I hope you getting along
all right. You must write
to me regularly. We are really
very near now. A telegram
in the morning would bring
me to Hatley on the same
evening.
